#Text=Bleach Pine Cones
#Text=Pinecones are plentiful in art stores and in some backyards and parks , making them a cost effective way to decorate a home any season of the year .
#Text=There are different ways to decorate pine cones , with bleaching being one of the most popular techniques .
#Text=Using just bleach , water , and a bucket , you can make bleached pine cones of your own .
#Text=The pine cones can end up having anything from a driftwood look to a blond tone , making this a way to add a unique flair to your interior design .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Preparing Your Materials
#Text=Dress in old clothes and put on protective gloves .
#Text=Because you will be working with bleach , which can permanently marr your clothing , make sure you are wearing old clothes that you wo n’t mind getting dirty .
#Text=You also want to wear rubber gloves to protect your hands from the bleach , which can irritate and even burn your skin .
#Text=Wear protective glasses , especially when pouring the bleach into the water .
#Text=You do n’t want any splashes getting into your eyes .
#Text=Gather your pine cones .
#Text=Make sure the pine cones are completely open and dry .
#Text=Wet and closed pine cones will not bleach well .
#Text=Put the pine cones in your bucket .
#Text=If you are working with a lot of pine cones , then a five gallon utility bucket will be best .
#Text=It will have enough room to allow the solution to cover all the pine cones .
#Text=But , if you are working with smaller pine cones , or with only one or two , then something smaller can work .
#Text=Add 2 parts water to 1 part bleach to the bucket .
#Text=Make sure there is enough solution to cover all the pine cones .
#Text=Soaking the Pine Cones
#Text=Put rocks or bricks on top of the pine cones to hold them down in the solution .
#Text=The pine cones will start to float , so you will need at least two rocks or bricks .
#Text=If some pine cones escape from under the rocks or bricks , then add another rock or brick to make sure they all stay down .
#Text=The pine cones will close up when they are wet .
#Text=That is supposed to happen and will not affect the bleaching .
#Text=Let the pine cones sit in the bleach water for up to 48 hours .
#Text=This will give the solution enough time to work .
#Text=Check the pine cones after 12 hours .
#Text=Some of the smaller pine cones might be ready .
#Text=Again , put on old clothes , the rubber gloves , and protective glasses to protect your skin and eyes .
#Text=Remove the rocks or bricks and start picking through the pine cones to see if any are ready .
#Text=Your own preference for color will determine if they are ready or not .
#Text=The longer you let the pine cones sit , the more bleached they will look .
#Text=The bleaching can range from a driftwood appearance to a blond look depending on how long the pine cones were submerged in the solution for .
#Text=Drying the Pine Cones
#Text=Remove the pine cones after 48 hours .
#Text=Put back on all the protective gear – the old clothes , gloves , and glasses – and gently take the pine cones out .
#Text=Remember that the pine cones will be covered in a bleach solution .
#Text=Wearing old dirty clothes , gloves , and protective glasses is advisable to protect your clothing , skin , and eyes .
#Text=Place the pine cones on a surface to dry .
#Text=A tarp , baking sheet , paper towel , or old towel that you wo n’t mind getting bleach on all will work .
#Text=The pine cones may take up to a week to dry .
#Text=Take them off the drying surface when they are dry and open again .
#Text=The pine cones should be as dry and open as they were before you poured the solution on them .
#Text=Bake the pine cones if you do n't want to wait a week .
#Text=After you take them out of the bleach solution , let them dry for 24 hours and then bake them at 250 degrees until they open .
#Text=Alternatively , if it is hot out , you can leave them in direct sunlight to speed up the drying process .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Wear old clothes to prevent the bleach ruining your good ones .
#Text=Work in a well ventilated area or outside .
#Text=The smell of the bleach can be strong .
#Text=Things
#Text=You 'll Need
#Text=Pinecones
#Text=Bleach
#Text=Large bucket ( a five gallon utility bucket works best )
#Text=Water
#Text=Rubber gloves
#Text=Large stones or bricks
